issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
We should validate the config of such that configs that dont work wont be accepted when the property is set.

I ran into a situation where I was able to launch instances but not get a network which caused me to dig into the eucanetd logs. 

Turns out, when the subnet configured by the network JSON is not a proper subnet (for example 10.0.1.0/16), dhcpd is unable to start. This causes the system to be in a state where it can run instances but they will not get network. I would also propose that the CC not go to ENABLED if a valid JSON is not present. 

The eucanetd log says something like:
{noformat}
2014-03-21 14:02:23  INFO | new networking state (VM public network addresses): updated successfully
2014-03-21 14:02:23  INFO | new networking state (VM network isolation): updated successfully
2014-03-21 14:02:24  INFO | new networking state (CLC IP metadata service): updating system
2014-03-21 14:02:24  INFO | new networking state (CLC IP metadata service): updated successfully
2014-03-21 14:02:24  INFO | new networking state (VM security groups): updating system
2014-03-21 14:02:24  INFO | new networking state (VM security groups): updated successfully
2014-03-21 14:02:24  INFO | new networking state (VM public/private network addresses, VM network isolation): updating system
2014-03-21 14:02:24 ERROR | command failed: exitcode='256' command='//usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_rootwrap /usr/sbin/dhcpd -cf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.conf -lf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.leases -pf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.pid -tf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.trace'
{noformat}


Additionally adding the output from the dhcpd  command in the eucanetd log would also be helpful as it yields:
{noformat}
[root@euca-10-0-1-189 ~]# /usr/sbin/dhcpd -cf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.conf -lf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.leases -pf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.pid -tf //var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.trace
Internet Systems Consortium DHCP Server 4.1.1-P1
Copyright 2004-2010 Internet Systems Consortium.
All rights reserved.
For info, please visit https://www.isc.org/software/dhcp/
WARNING: Overwriting trace file "//var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.trace"
//var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.conf line 7: subnet 10.0.1.0 netmask 255.255.0.0: bad subnet number/mask combination.
subnet 10.0.1.0 netmask 255.255.0.0
                                  ^
WARNING: Host declarations are global.  They are not limited to the scope you declared them in.
//var/run/eucalyptus/net/euca-dhcp.conf line 19: empty shared-network decl
}
 ^
Configuration file errors encountered -- exiting

This version of ISC DHCP is based on the release available
on ftp.isc.org.  Features have been added and other changes
have been made to the base software release in order to make
it work better with this distribution.

Please report for this software via the CentOS Bugs Database:
    http://bugs.centos.org/

exiting.
{noformat}
fields.summary: Add parameter validation for Edge JSON

comments.body:
All,

I can (and may) put some checking logic on the back-end (XML validation) side to check for correct settings, but I would like to point out that, currently, the broadcastnetworkinfo operation is not part of any control flow between the back-end and front-end (i.e. it really is a broadcast), so even if/when checking is done on the back-end, the system will still behave in a very odd way if such a configuration makes it all the way down.  In other words, even with this type of checking on the back-end, the user would still be able to run instances even though they would never actually be able to come up on the network.

In order to address that issue, the front-end would have to do the checks upon configuration upload, in order to prevent an invalid configuration from being present in the first place.  

I'll wait for this conversation to proceed before adding more strict validation code on the back-end 

-D
Adding some more configuration validation is easy enough, but a description of all required validation rules is the first step.

[~nurmi],

Would you do me the honor of taking the next step with a first cut at rules for each parameter.

Here is a first cut:

- InstanceDnsDomain: string that should comply with hostname format restrictions (rfc1123 I believe is current) - dot separated strings of length 1 to 63, entire string no greater than 255 characters.  valid characters are 'a-z', '0-9' and '-'.  I got most of this from wikipedia (but looked at the referenced RFC as well)

- InstanceDnsServers: list of strings that are IP addresses (just the IP, no CIDR '/')

- PublicIPs: list of strings that are either a single IP address, or a range of IP addresses strictly of the form 'a.b.c.d-w.x.y.z'.  no spaces

- PrivateIps: same as PublicIps, but unused for 4.0 EDGE

- Subnets: list of 'subnets', each of which has a 'Name', 'Subnet', 'Netmask' and 'Gateway'.  
    -- 'Name' and 'Subnet' are identical strings
    -- all should pass IP address format check
    -- 'Netmask' must be a value that represents a bit string with leading consecutive 1's, followed by 0's.  valid decimal values for each part are [ 255, 254, 252, 248, 240, 224, 192, 128, 0 ].  Since the final netmask bit string must be leading with consecutive ones followed by zeros, the netmask must additionally have a form (for example if the netmask string were a.b.c.d) where a >= b >= c >= d.  There may be some other way of checking that the string is 1's followed by 0's, but nothing immediately comes to my mind :)
    -- 'Subnet' must be the first value in a network that can be described by combining 'Subnet' and 'Netmask'.  I believe the simplest check is to ensure that 'Subnet & Netmask == Subnet'.
    -- 'Gateway' must be an IP within the subnet defined by 'Subnet' and 'Netmask', with a simple check being '(Gateway != Subnet) && (Gateway & Netmask == Subnet)'

For each Cluster...

- 'Name': must be the name of a currently registered cluster (judgement call on this one, but in any case a cluster should not go to enabled until there is a matching complete configuration section in here with a cluster name that matches the registered cluster)
- 'MacPrefix': string of the form 'WX:YZ' where W, X, Y, and Z are characters that represent a valid hexidecimal value 0-F.  
- 'Subnet': one subnet, of the form listed above for 'Subnets'
- 'PrivateIPs': same as above 'PublicIPs'


Overall, all values for each 'Cluster' must be populated.  'Subnets' and 'PrivateIps' in the global section are optional, everything else is mandatory ATM.  We need to re-evaluate whether 'PublicIPs' should be made optional in the case where a user wants to use private-only addressing entirely.

look right Steve/Vic?

-D

[~nurmi], I thought the subnet name was an arbitrary identifier, if it must be the same as the subnet (in the broadcast) then I will need to update this.

The configured private IP addresses are used in 4.0, but perhaps not by the backend.

The described rules relate to the broadcast format rather than the configuration format, but I can translate into rules that relate to the configuration format.

Steve,

| Daniel Nurmi, I thought the subnet name was an arbitrary identifier, if it must be the same as the subnet (in the broadcast) then I will need to update this.

right - this is currently true (name must == subnet) in the broadcast, on the back-end

| The configured private IP addresses are used in 4.0, but perhaps not by the backend.

PrivateIPs in the global section are not being used by the back-end : can you describe how they would be used if specified, by the front-end?  i.e. does the CLC then decide which privateIPs belong to which clusters and populate the broadcast XML accordingly?  The back-end needs a list of privateIPs in the 'cluster' section of the broadcast XML in order for EDGE/eucanetd to function.

| The described rules relate to the broadcast format rather than the configuration format, but I can translate into rules that relate to the configuration format.

some of it does, but I was using the configuration format names (InstanceDnsDomain, PublicIps, etc.) to describe the rules with the intention of describing the format for the configuration (not just the broadcast XML).  Just want to make sure we're on the same page - was there something in my description that you know only applies to the broadcast XML format (and doesn't apply to the configuration format)?

_D

[~nurmi],

I think the differences are only in which values are required and where default values come from.

In the configuration format, the subnet name is an arbitrary identifier but if omitted the name defaults to the subnet. In the network configuration you can specify values at the top level and these are used in the cluster if there is no value specified at the cluster level (e.g. private ip addresses, mac address prefix, subnet). This means in the simple case you do not have to specify any cluster configuration. Private IP address configuration is optional and will default to all values in the clusters subnet (excluding the gateway)

For each cluster you can specify a subnet by name and the values will be copied from the global subnet with that name.

If values are omitted in the network configuration we fall back to using the equivalent cloud property (when one is available)
Can we remove the redundant subnet/name parameters if they must be the same anyway?

Can we just remove the redundant subnet or name parameters?


On Mon, Mar 24, 2014 at 12:38 PM, Steve Jones (JIRA) <




-- 

*_________________________*

*Victor Iglesias - *Director of Quality and Release

*Eucalyptus Systems*

www.eucalyptus.com

Follow us on Twitter <http://twitter.com/#!/eucalyptus>

Like our Facebook
Page<http://www.facebook.com/pages/Eucalyptus-Systems-Inc/164828240204708>

Keep up-to-date with
us<http://go.eucalyptus.com/Sign-Up-for-Cloud-Computing-News.html?Offer=Other&OfferDetails=Sign%20Up%20for%20Cloud%20Computing%20News&LeadSourceDetails=Eucalyptus%20Website&OfferURL=http%3A%2F%2Fgo.eucalyptus.com%2FSign-Up-for-Cloud-Computing-News.html>

*_________________________*
[~viglesias], they do not have to the be same in the network configuration, i.e. you can use a descriptive name. I need to translate this for the broadcast so they are the same for the backend.
I opened EUCA-8956 for the subnet name issue as that is not related to validation.

The following validation checks/errors are added:

{code}
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid domain "InstanceDnsDomain": ".eucalyptus.internal"
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid IP "InstanceDnsServers[0]": "a8.8.8.8"
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid netmask for "Clusters[0].Subnet.Netmask": "255.255.193.0"
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid subnet due to netmask for subnet "Clusters[0].Subnet": "172.26.64.1"
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid gateway due to subnet/netmask for subnet "Clusters[0].Subnet": "173.26.64.1"
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid MAC prefix "MacPrefix": "ag:aa"
{code}

There were existing validation checks for IP address values/ranges, other checks are not relevant for the configuration.

Fix Verified

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.0.0
Release     : 0.0.933.20140425git7b29dad4.el6

Parameter validation for network configuration json is performed
{code}
[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid domain "InstanceDnsDomain": ".eucalyptus.internal"

[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid IP "InstanceDnsServers[0]": "x10.111.5.20"

[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid MAC prefix "Clusters[0].MacPrefix": "g0:0d"

[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid netmask for "Clusters[0].Subnet.Netmask": "255.255.193.0"

[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid subnet due to netmask for subnet "Clusters[0].Subnet": "172.32.64.1"

[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid gateway due to subnet/netmask for subnet "Clusters[0].Subnet": "172.32.64.0"
{code}

also checked with multiple clusters ex.
{code}
[root@h-20 ~]# euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=net-conf-bad
Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Invalid gateway due to subnet/netmask for subnet "Clusters[1].Subnet": "172.32.64.0"
{code}
